H0.text: who stepped out of the dithyrambic chorus to become the first actor. Aeschylus

H1.text: who stepped out of the dithyrambic chorus to become the first actor. Sophocles

H2.text: who stepped out of the dithyrambic chorus to become the first actor. Euripides

H3.text: who stepped out of the dithyrambic chorus to become the first actor. Thespis

A4.text: Aeschylus added a second actor instead of the choir.

A5.text: Aeschylus foregrounded the dialogue by increasing the number of actors and reducing the role of the chorus in his works.

A6.text: The importance of the chorus declined after the 5th century BCE, when the chorus began to be separated from the dramatic action.

A7.text: Thespis is often called the 'Inventor of Tragedy'.

A8.text: He was the winner of the first theatrical contest held in Athens.
